contentrichtext.text: '''Quest Aerospace''' is a company based in [[Pagosa Springs, CO]], [[USA]] that designs and produces [[model rocket]] kits. Quest Aerospace was founded in 1992 by [[Bill Stine]] (son of [[G. Harry Stine]]), and produces model rocket kits for various skill levels of modelers, from the beginner to the most highly skilled. In 1995, ToyBiz (now Marvel Entertainment) acquired Quest along with Spectra Star, Inc.<ref name=fdu>{{cite web|title=Toy Biz, Inc. -- Company History|url=http://www.fundinguniverse.com/company-histories/Toy-Biz-Inc-Company-History.html|work=fundinguniverse.com|accessdate=12 April 2011}}</ref> In 2003, Bill Stine purchased back Quest Aerospace from Marvel.<ref>{{cite web| title=NARCON 2011 Presentations |url=http://www.narcon.org/schedule/schedule/presentations.html |work=NARCON |publisher=Washington Aerospace Club |accessdate=10 May 2011}}</ref> Quest's products include model rockets powered by standard 18 mm motors as well as smaller rockets powered by Micro Maxx motors. The company produces both 18 mm motors and Micro Maxx motors for use in its model rocket kits. Powered by compressed [[black powder]] motors, some of these rockets can achieve altitudes of over 2000 feet. {{citation needed|date=November 2011}} ==In Popular Culture== The name Quest Aerospace was used in the 2002 film [[Spider-Man (2002 film)|''Spider-Man'']], based on the [[Marvel Comics]] character [[Spider-Man|of the same name.]] Quest was a competitor of [[Oscorp]], the company owned by [[Green Goblin|Norman Osborn]] (aka the Green Goblin). Quest was competing with Oscorp to sell an exoskeleton to the US Military and after the Green Goblin destroyed it the company restructured and was going to purchase Oscorp before the Goblin killed the Oscorp board of directors. ==References== {{Reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.questaerospace.com Go to the Quest Aerospace Website] [[Category:Companies based in Colorado]] {{rocketry-stub}}
